page.title: 07Carmelite Convent.
page.content: The convent built in 1917 takes about 5 acres of land. The nuns' main work is to make communion wafers of flour and water, spreading it onto hot plates and a lid is brought down which prints the pattern. The brittle sheets are then put onto shelves in a warm room to soften, then put through a machine which cuts the wafers. They are packed into boxes, and sent to churches in the diocese. The nuns make 100,000 small wafers per week and nearly 3,000-4,000 larger wafers. They also make jumpers, dolls, cribs, shell ornaments, decorate egg shells, keep poultry and have two hives of bees. The nuns' rooms called cells are very simple. Mass is celebrated daily at 8.00am. the day starts at 5.30a.m. and they go to their cells at 10.30pm. There are 17 nuns and one postulant.
